seen, this independence exists in the case of the <u>Orbitolite</u> to such a degree
as to make each part entirely self sustaining, and to prevent the existence
of any definite limit to the growth of the whole; yet it is quite possible
that in a form so much more elevated as <u>Nummulite</u>, there may
be, as maintained by M. M.D'Archiac and Haime (op. cit p 69) such
a degree of mutual dependence among the segments, and of unity
in their aggregate life, that the latter predominates sufficiently
to limit the growth of the organism to a tolerably determinate
size. [<u>Note</u>. Whilst admitting the possibility of this view, I shall
hereafter have occasion to question its correctness; since the
evidence on which it is based, appears to me by no means
satisfactory. In fact, when I come to describe (in a future
memoir) the structure and varieties of
<u>Nonionina</u>, the nearest
existing type to Nummulite, and in my belief generically
identical with it, I shall have occasion to show that, there
is not only no proof of the existence of such a limitation to its
growth, but that there is strong evidence to the contrary.]

43  The mode of <u>reproduction</u> of the Foraminifera generally
